snippet.title: 8-Types of RAGs and their Use Cases | Rakesh Gohel
snippet.description:
If you want to learn about how to utilize RAG to the fullest and how to build a capable Agentic RAG systems. 

Make sure to join, AI Agent Engineering course, where you'll learn to design RAG-powered agents with an enterprise mindset.

ðŸ“— Enroll here: https://lnkd.in/gA3zhcfm

1\. Naive RAG

- Direct retrieval with no sophisticated filtering or feedback
- Example: Customer support chatbots answering FAQs from documentation

2\. Agentic RAG

- Autonomous planning, tool use, and dynamic retrieval strategies
- Example: Competitive intelligence analysts who autonomously monitor and analyze competitor data

3\. HyDE (Hypothetical Document Embeddings)

- Generates "hypothetical" documents for better retrieval matching
- Example: Adaptive Technical search where users describe problems differently than usual

4\. Graph RAG

- Structures data as knowledge graphs for richer contextual reasoning
- Example: Medical support systems generating hypothetical patient cases based on symptom relationships

5\. Corrective RAG

- Iterative self-correction to improve retrieval accuracy
- Example: Financial report analysis that self-corrects when retrieving across multiple data sources

6\. Contextual RAG

- Adapts retrieval by interpreting broader conversational context
- Example: Meeting assistants understanding strategic discussions across multiple sessions

7\. Modular RAG

- Composable, plug-and-play modules for custom workflows
- Example: Custom workflows combining multiple retrieval processes and specialized tools

8\. Hybrid RAG

- Mixes semantic search and embedding-based retrieval
- Example: Legal research combining exact statutory citations with semantic principle matching

ðŸ“Œ Quick Selection Guide:

- Naive RAG â†’ Simple knowledge base Q&A
- Agentic RAG â†’ Complex autonomous workflows with tool integration
- HyDE â†’ Query-document vocabulary mismatch scenarios
- Graph RAG â†’ Interconnected data requiring relationship reasoning
- Corrective RAG â†’ High-accuracy requirements with verification needs
- Contextual RAG â†’ Multi-turn conversations needing memory
- Modular RAG â†’ Custom enterprise pipelines with multiple retrieval steps
- Hybrid RAG â†’ Mixed semantic understanding and exact retrieval
